conclusion: Each book weighs 5 N, divided into equal parts and stacked alternately, horizontal force F applied to pull out book B.
The force F needed to pull the book is related to the frictional forces between the sheets.
The frictional force f between two surfaces is given by f = μN, where N is the normal force (pressure).
When the books are divided into n parts, each part of book A exerts a normal force on the corresponding part of book B.
The total normal force N is the sum of the weights of the parts of book A that are in contact with book B.
For n = 2 divisions, the force F = 4.5 N.
For n = 4 divisions, the force F = 10.5 N.
For n = 8 divisions, the force F = 22.5 N.
For n = 16 divisions, the force F = 46.5 N.
For complete page-by-page proofreading (n divisions), the force F = 190.5 N.
The force F increases with the number of divisions n because more surfaces are in contact, increasing the total frictional force.
For each division, the normal force N increases by half the weight of the book (2.5 N) because each part of book A exerts this force on book B.
The total frictional force is the sum of the frictional forces for each division.
For n divisions, the total normal force is N = n/2 × 5 N.
Using the data for n = 2: F = 4.5 N, N = 5 N, 4.5 = μ × 5.
